nodes.text: Dynamics of piecewise translation maps
Sang Truong
University of California, Irvine
Abstract
In this pap er, we intro duce a generalized piecewise translation map on the Euclidean
space. We provide a special case when this map is always of finite type. For a finite
type map in this case, we form conjectures on the semi-continuity of the attractor.
Moreover, we also provide some conjectures and pictures on piecewise translations on
a two dimensional torus.
1 Background
The goal of this pap er is to study the dynamics of piecewise translation maps. These maps
are special types of piecewise isometries on a region Ω in the Euclidean space. To define
piecewise isometries, we partition Ω into smaller regions P0, · · · , Pm such that these pieces
intersect only at their boundaries. We also assume that the b oundary of each piece has zero
Lebesgue measure. A map f : Ω → Ω is called a piecewise isometry if the restriction of f
to any piece Pi is an isometry, i.e. it preserves distance on each piece. Piecewise isometries,
especially piecewise translation maps, serve as models for many engineering applications,
such as the second order digital filter [6, 7], the sigma-delta mo dulator [3, 8, 10], the buck
converter [7, 9], the three-capacitance model [16], error diffusion in digital printing [1, 2],
and machine learning.
One of the simplest examples of such piecewise translation can b e formed using interval
exchange transformations (IET). These transformations are a generalization of a classical
dynamical system – circle rotation. To define an IET, let Ω = [0, 1) ⊆ R be partitioned into
a finite number of distinct intervals. The map f : Ω → Ω that permutes the intervals defines
a piecewise isometry.
Several nice properties of IET have been discovered. In particular, M. Kean [14] showed that
every orbit of f is dense in [0, 1). He also proved that if the partition has only two or three
IMAGE
Figure 1: Interval Exchange Transformation (IET)
intervals, then all minimal IETs are also uniquely ergodic. The statement is not necessarily
true if the numb er of intervals exceeds 3. However, it was proven by Masur [15] and Veech
[20] that almost every interval exchange transformation is uniquely ergodic. This motivates
a generalized conjecture that most piecewise isometries (restriction to the attractors) are
also uniquely ergodic.
We can also consider a variation of interval exchange transformations, namely interval trans-
lation mappings (ITM). These mappings are introduced by M. Boshernitzan and I. Kornfeld
in 1995 [5]. For ITM, the images of the intervals are not required to b e disjoint. We clas-
sify ITM into two types: finite and infinite. In the case f (Ω) ̸= Ω, consider the sequence
Ω0 = Ω, Ω1 = f (Ω0 ), . . .. From this, we get the nested chain Ω0 ⊇ Ω1 ⊇ . . .. If this chain
stabilizes we say the map f : Ω → Ω is of finite type; otherwise, f is of infinite type. We
see that the map can only be of infinite typ e if there are more than two elements in the
partition. In particular, Boshernitzan and Kornfield constructed an ITM of infinite type
with three branches [5].
Another class of one dimensional piecewise isometries is the double rotations of the circle.
Let Ω = S 1 = [0, 1]/{0 ∼ 1} be partitioned into two arcs P0 and P1. We define the double
rotation map f : S1 → S1 as following:
f (x) = (cid:26) x + α0 (mod 1), if x ∈ P0 ; x + α1 (mod 1), if x ∈ P1 .
Almost all double rotations of the circle are uniquely ergo dic, even most of those of infinite
typ e [4]. We would like to emphasize that this text is the result of an undergraduate research
IMAGE
Figure 2: Piecewise translation of 3 branches on a 2-dimensional disk.
pro ject under the guidance of Prof. Gorodetski, based on the original ideas and results from
[13] and [19]. The pictures were inspired by those from [13] and [19], but were recreated by
indep endent repro duction of their numerical experiments.
2 General set-up
Let Ω be a compact set in the Euclidean space Rd. Suppose Ω = (cid:83)m−1i=0 Bi where Bi ’s are
compact for all i = 0, 1, . . . , m − 1. Here we allow the subsets Bi ’s to have non-trivial inter-
sections. We define a translation map on each Bi ’s by Ti (x) = x + vi, where vi is a vector in
Rd . Let X be the space of all compact subsets of Ω.
Definition 2.1. The map F : X → X , F (K) = (cid:83)m−1i=0 Ti(K ∩ Bi) is called a piecewise
translation of m branches on Ω.
Each Bi is called a branch of Ω. Lo cally, if x is in both Bi and Bj , then x will b e translated by
both vi and vj . Figure 2 represents a piecewise translation of 3 branches on a 2-dimensional
disk. These three branches intersect only at their b oundaries, which have zero Lebesgue
measure. Figure 2 is a simplified model of machine learning. In order for the machine to
learn, we need multiple inputs from the environment. Each input is represented by a trans-
lation vector. The process of machine learning is modeled by the dynamics of applying the
piecewise translation map many times. Therefore, it is natural to define what we get after
applying the map over and over again, which we will call the attractor.
Definition 2.2. The set A = (cid:84)∞n=1 F n(Ω) is called the attractor of the map F . If A = F N (Ω)
for some N ∈ N, then we say the map F (or the attractor A) is of finite type. Otherwise, F
is of infinite type.
Because {F n(Ω)}∞n=1 is a non-increasing sequence of non-empty compact sets, it has a non-
empty intersection. Therefore, the attractor is always non-empty and compact. Moreover,
the attractor should be invariant under the map F . This expected property is a direct con-
sequence of the following lemma.
Lemma 2.1. Let K0 ⊇ K1 ⊇ . . . is a non-increasing sequence of non-empty compact sets
in X , then F ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn) = (cid:84)∞n=0 F (Kn).
Proof. The inclusion F ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn) ⊆ (cid:84)∞n=0 F (Kn) is trivial. In order to show the other
direction, let x ∈ (cid:84)∞n=0 F (Kn), then x ∈ F (Kn) for all n ∈ N. Let H = {y ∈ Ω | F ({y}) ∋ x}.
Note that H is a finite union of compact sets, hence is compact. Indeed, H has finitely many
points in Ω. Since x ∈ F (Kn) for all n, the sets Hn = H ∩ Kn are non-empty. So {Hn}∞n=0
is a non-increasing sequence of non-empty compact s ets. Therefore it has a non-empty
intersection; i.e. ∃y ∈ H such that y ∈ (cid:84)∞n=0 Kn . As a consequence, {x} ⊆ F ({y}) ⊆
F ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn). This shows that x ∈ F ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn ).
Corollary 2.1. The attractor is invariant under the map F ; i.e. F (A) = A.
In some cases, a small change in the translation vectors v0, v1 , . . . , vm−1 leads to a huge
change in the geometry of A. In other words, A is not “continuous” in the parameter space.
It is convenient to introduce the Hausdorff metric on X to study the continuity of A. Here
we denote the ε-neighborhood of a set X with the standard Euclidean metric by Xε. We will
show that the orbit of Ω gets arbitrarily close to the attractor with respect to the Hausdorff
metric.
Definition 2.3. Let X, Y ∈ X , the Hausdorff distance b etween X and Y is defined by
dH (X, Y ) = inf {ε > 0 | X ⊆ Yε and Y ⊆ Xε}.
Lemma 2.2. Let K0 ⊇ K1 ⊇ . . . be a non-increasing sequence of non-empty compact sets
in X . For every ε > 0, there exists N ∈ N such that KN ⊆ ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn)ε.
Proof. Denote Sn = Kn \ ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn )ε , then Sn are compact and S0 ⊇ S1 ⊇ . . . If all Sn are
non-empty, then they have a non-empty intersection. This leads to ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn ) \ ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn)ε ̸=
∅ (contradiction ). Therefore, ∃N ∈ N such that SN = ∅, which means KN ⊆ ((cid:84)∞n=0 Kn)ε
Corollary 2.2. For every ε > 0, there exists N ∈ N such that dH (A, F n(Ω)) < ε for all
n ≥ N .
3 Finiteness theorem when m = d + 1
In this section, we are interested in piecewise translation maps of m = d + 1 branches in
Rd . We assume that rank{v0, v1 , . . . , vm−1 } = d; that is, the vectors in B = {v1 − v0 , v2 −
v0 , . . . , vm−1 − v0} form a basis for Rd. Let L be the lattice generated by B , then T = Rd/L
is a d-dimensional torus. In this case, v0 serves as the translation vector in T; i.e. we have
the torus rotation map R : T → T, R(x + L) = x + v0 + L. Atom-wise, the action of F is the
same as the action of R on T. Globally, it is also true and can be seen through the canonical
pro jection π : Rd → T, π(x) = x + L.
Lemma 3.1. If K ⊆ Ω is compact, then π ◦ F (K ) = R ◦ π (K ).
Proof. Let ϕ ∈ π ◦ T (K ), then ϕ ∈ (cid:83)m−1i=1 π(Ti (Bi ∩ K )). So ϕ = π(Tj (Bj ∩ K )) for some j.
Therefore, ∃y ∈ Bj ∩ K such that ϕ = π(y + vj ). As a result,
ϕ = y + vj + L = y + v0 + (vj − v0 ) + L = y + v0 + L = R ◦ π(y) ∈ R ◦ π (K ).
For the backward inclusion, let ϕ ∈ R ◦ π (K ), then ϕ = R ◦ π (y ) = y + v0 + L for some y ∈ K .
Without loss of generality, we can assume y ∈ Bj . In this case, ϕ = π (y +vj ) ∈ π (Tj (Bj ∩K )).
Hence, x ∈ π ◦ F (K ).
It was proven that any piecewise translation of an interval with 2 branches is of finite type
[18]. However, this does not hold for dimension 2 or higher. Indeed, not all double rotation
on a torus is of finite type. In the case where m = d + 1, there is a space of parameters
(translation vectors) where we will get finite typ e attractors. We assume that the transla-
tion vectors v0, v1 , . . . , vm−1 are rationally independent, i.e. they are linearly independent in
Q-vector space. This is equivalent for the toral map R to be ergodic. In this case, we say
that the translation vectors are minimal. With this assumption, the map F is necessarily of
finite typ e. We start with some definitions that will be used in the proof.
Definition 3.1. A set X is said to b e invariant under the map f : M → M if f (X ) = X .
Definition 3.2. A toral map R : T → T is said to be minimal if every orbit is dense; i.e
there is no proper closed invariant subset.
Definition 3.3. A set X ⊆ Rd is nowhere dense if int ¯A = ∅.
Theorem 3.1. Piecewise translation maps with rationally independent translation vectors
are of finite type.
Proof. The idea is to show that F N (Ω) is contained in some ε-neighborhood of A but not
contained in ε-neighborhood of ∂ A for some N > 0. In this case, F N (Ω) must b e in the
interior of A, thus a subset of A.
Since A is compact, non-empty and π is continuous, π (A) is compact and non-empty. More-
over, R ◦ π (A) = π ◦ F (A) = π(A) by Lemma 2.1, so π(A) is invariant under R. We know
that ergo dic torus rotation is minimal; therefore, there is no proper closed invariant sets.
Since π (A) is non-empty, π(A) = T. Since A is closed, ∂ A is nowhere dense in Rd. Since
Ω is compact, the pro jection π is at most finitely branched, so lo cally π (∂A) is a finite
union of nowhere dense sets, and thus is nowhere dense in T. Therefore, we can take a small
ball B in the complement of π(∂ A) and ε > 0 such that for U = (π(∂ A))ε we have U ∩ B = ∅.
By Lemma 2.2, there exists N > 0 such that F n (Ω) ⊆ Aε for all n > N . So we only
need to show that F n(Ω) is not in (∂A)ε if n is large enough. It is known that every ergo dic
toral rotation map is uniformly minimal; i.e. for the open set B , there exists M > 0 such
that ∀ϕ ∈ T, Rk (ϕ) ϕ ∈ B for some 0 < k(ϕ) < M . Note that k depends on ϕ while M do es
not.
Claim: π ◦ F n+k ({x}) ∩ U = ∅ for some 0 < k < M .
Indeed, we can apply Lemma 3.1 and the uniformly minimal property for ϕ = Rn ◦ π(x):
Since π is continuous, we can cho ose a positive δ < ε such that π((∂ A)δ ) ⊆ (π(∂ A))ε = U .
Hence π◦ F n+k ({x}) ∩ U = ∅. Therefore, F n+k({x}) ∩ (∂ A)ϵ = ∅. This leads to F n+k ({x}) ⊆
int A ⊆ A. Since k = k (x) is uniformly bounded by M , we have F N +M (Ω) ⊆ A, i.e. the
map F is of finite type.
4 Semi-continuity of the attractors
In general, it is not true that the attractor is continuous with respect to Hausdorff metric in
the parameter space. Even in the case m = d + 1, we observed that sometimes the two sepa-
rate pieces of the attractor reglue to each other. One of our concerns has not b een proven yet.
Question 4.1. Is it true that for a generic family of partitions, the attractor depends con-
tinuously on the translation vectors?
IMAGE
Figure 3: The black regions represent F n(D2) for n = 1, 2, 8, 9.
The disk converges to the attractor after 8 iterations. The map is of finite type.
However, in the case m = d + 1, the question of semi-continuity of the attractor is easier
to answer. We will show that for a particular family of partitions, finite typ e attractors are
semi-continuous on the translation vectors. Before showing the proof for this, we need a
formal definition for semi-continuity of the attractors.
Definition 4.1. Let W be the space of translation vectors such that the associated piecewise
translation map Fv0 ,v1,...,vm−1 is of finite type with a fixed partition B. Denote Xa the attrac-
tor associated with the parameter a ∈ W . We say that the attractors are semi-continuous
on W if for every a ∈ W , there exists a neighb orho od O (a) such that for each b ∈ O (a), we
have Xb ⊆ (Xa )ε.
Note that the semi-continuity of the attractor corresp onds to the pseudo -Hausdorff metric
d(X, Y ) = sup{d(x, Y ) | x ∈ X }. It is clear that
dH (X, Y ) = max{d(X, Y ), d(Y , X )}.
Conjecture 4.1. If m = d +1, there exists a generic parameter value such that the attractors
are semi-continuous in W .
5 Piecewise translation maps on tori
In this section, we discuss a special class of piecewise translations of two branches on a two
dimensional torus called double rotations. Double rotations were discussed in [17] and [11].
Synchronization prop erties of random double rotations on tori were studied in [12]. Here we
will show some pictures of double rotations with finite and infinite types.
Definition 5.1. Let T be a two-dimensional torus and v0 , v1 are vectors in R2. Consider a
subset R of T. The map f : T → T defined as
f (x) = (cid:26) x + v0 (mod 1), if x ∈ R; x + v1 (mod 1), otherwise
is called a double rotation on T.
In Figure 4, the torus is partitioned into two regions - green and blue. We assign a different
translation vector to each region. After applying the map, we see that a region from the
torus is lost (the red region). In this case, it is the translational image of the green region.
Applying the map one more time, we get an additional lost region. Again, this is a transla-
tional image of the previous red region. After 500 times, we no longer get any additional lost
region. The map is of finite type and its attractor is the blue part in Figure 5. On the other
hands, in Figure 6, we do not get the attractor even after 5000 iterates. The map seems to
be of infinite typ e.
Let V be the space of parameters {v0 , v1 } with a fixed partition such that the double rota-
tion map fv0,v1 is of finite type. By computer simulation, we conjecture that the map is of
finite type for almost every parameter. If the map is finite, we also expect the attractor is
semi-continuous with respect to Hausdorff distance. This behavior has already b een seen in
the previous section.
Conjecture 5.1. V is an open, dense, and full measure subset of the set of all parameters.
Conjecture 5.2. The attractor is semi-continuous with resp ect to the parameters in V .
Question 5.1. Is it true that the attractor is continuous with respect to the parameters in
V ?
IMAGE
Figure 4: Double rotation on a torus T. The green rectangle
indicates the smaller region. The blue parts represent f n(T) for n = 0, 1, 2, 3.
IMAGE
Figure 5: The blue part is the attractor of the map in Figure 4.
The attractor is attained after 500 iterates. The map is of finite typ e.
IMAGE
Figure 6: Seemingly infinite type attractor.
